resource.name: triton_firewall_rule
resource.description: The `triton_firewall_rule` resource represents a rule for the Triton cloud firewall.

arguments.argument: The firewall rule described using the Cloud API rule syntax defined at https://docs.joyent.com/public-cloud/network/firewall/cloud-firewall-rules-reference.
Whether the rule should be effective.

attributes.attribute: The identifier representing the firewall rule in Triton.

example.description: Allow traffic on ports tcp/80 and tcp/443 to machines with the 'www' tag from any source
Block traffic on port tcp/143 to all machines

resource.name: triton_key
resource.description: The `triton_key` resource represents an SSH key for a Triton account.

arguments.argument: The name of the key. If this is left empty, the name is inferred from the comment in the SSH key material.
The SSH key material. In order to read this from a file, use the `file` interpolation.

resource.name: triton_machine
resource.description: The `triton_machine` resource represents a virtual machine or infrastructure container running in Triton.

arguments.argument: The friendly name for the machine. Triton will generate a name if one is not specified.
A mapping of tags to apply to the machine.
The name of the package to use for provisioning.
The UUID of the image to provision.
A list of the IDs of the desired networks for the machine.
Whether the cloud firewall should be enabled for this machine.
The public keys authorized for root access via SSH to the machine.
Data to be copied to the machine on boot.
The user script to run on boot (every boot on SmartMachines).
The initial password for the Administrator user. Only used for Windows virtual machines.

attributes.attribute: The identifier representing the firewall rule in Triton.
The type of the machine (`smartmachine` or `virtualmachine`).
The current state of the machine.
The dataset URN with which the machine was provisioned.
The amount of memory the machine has (in Mb).
The amount of disk the machine has (in Gb).
The primary (public) IP address for the machine.
The time at which the machine was created.
The time at which the machine was last updated.
